dc:description:
*TTN* was first reported in association with autosomal dominant hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) in humans in 2009 (Arimura et al. 2009, PMID 19608031). *TTN* gene encodes titin protein which is a large protein in the sarcomere. There are multiple transcripts with N2BA and N2B as the primary cardiac transcripts. Many variants in *TTN* have been reported in individuals with HCM but the majority are missense without functional data or located in an exon with low percent spliced in (PSI) for cardiac tissue. There is one report of a frameshift located in the A-band (PSI 100%) (Sepp et al. 2022, PMID 35626289), and one termination in the I-band (PSI 100%) (Micheu et al. 2020, PMID 33297573) in individuals with HCM. Also of note, Higashikuse et al. (2019, PMID 31628103) provide strong functional data for two missense variants in the MURF1 binding region.   

Case-control data is contradictory towards an association with HCM. No excess *TTN* variants were noted in cases compared to controls in two studies (Herman et al. 2012, PMID 22335739, Zhang et al. 2017, 28822653). An additional study reported a higher proportion of controls with *TTN* truncations and missense variants compared to cases (Mademont-Soler et al. 2017, PMID: 28771489).
 
The gene-disease association is supported by expression studies in the human heart and animal models (Collins et al. 1996, PMID 8841931, Wang et al. 1999, PMID 10093045, Ponten et al. 2008, PMID 18853439, GTEX Consortium 2013, PMID 23715323). Protein interactions and biochemical function studies show Titin interacts with other sarcomere proteins associated with HCM (Freiburg et al. 2009, PMID 8631348, Frazier et al. 2011, PMID 21297871, Satoh et al, 1999, PMID 10462489). Previous mouse models showed homozygous individuals developed signs of HCM (Peng et al. 2007, PMID 17261657, Granzier et al. 2009, PMID 19679835). Most notably, a medaka fish model created through ENU mutagenesis developed features of HCM, and positional cloning led to a *TTN* missense variant in the MURF1 binding region (Higashikuse et al. 2019, PMID 31628103). 

This classification was originally approved by the ClinGen Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel on December 12, 2016. This gene-disease relationship was re-evaluated on July 27, 2023 by the Hereditary Cardiovascular Disorders GCEP. While more points were initially scored for the gene-disease relationship, the classification was downgraded to Limited due to the contradictory case-control data and limited case-level evidence. As a result of this re-evaluation, the classification did not change.

This classification pair was last evaluated by the Hereditary Cardiovascular disease GCEP on July 27, 2023. It was reevaluated on October 28, 2025 (SOP v11). Scoring for two cases (PMIDs 28822653, 33297573) carrying truncating variants in *TTN* (TTNtv) was reduced from 0.1 to 0 to reflect the frequency of TTNtv in the population. Additionally, two missense and a TTNtv were added to the curation (PMIDs 39895828, 38880420) but were all scored 0 due to variant type, population frequency or lack of functional evidence of variant impact. The score modifications and additional cases do not change the classification.
curationReasonDescription: While more points were initially scored for the gene-disease relationship, the classification was downgraded to Limited due to the contradictory case-control data and limited case-level evidence.

Truncation variants in TTN (TTNtv) are common in the population - no functional evidence for variant impact - gnomAD v4.1 Popmax 0.000000849 (European non Finnish)
Non-essential splice site variant
Missense variants are common in TTN. Located in the I band (PSI 3%)
Benign missense mutations in TTN are common, no evidence for pathogenic role - not scored.
missense variants in TTN are common, ANKRD1 is not definitively established to be associated with HCM
mutations increased binding of titin/connectin to CARP
Not enough segregations and confounding variables

While this variant is in the I-band (PSI 100%), truncations are common in the general population for TTN (see case control data). Without any functional data we were not able to score

controlCohort.detectionMethod: Next-generation or dideoxy sequencing. Only looked at truncating mutations.

evidence.dc:description: No excess in cases over controls. 7/13 TTN+ve cases also carried a sarcomere gene variant.

caseCohort.detectionMethod: Next-generation sequencing of N2B and Novex-3 transcripts. Only looked at truncating mutations.

controlCohort.detectionMethod: Next-generation sequencing of N2B and Novex-3 transcripts. Only looked at truncating mutations.

evidence.dc:description: Truncating variants were not seen with any frequency in the HCM cohort. Missense variants were seen in both cohorts. Missense variants in TTN have not been shown to cause cardiomyopathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: HCM vs controls without structural heart disease

evidence.dc:description: FHL2 has not been implicated in HCM

evidence.dc:description: Titin is a componant of the sarcomere, as are known HCM genes - shared biochemical function.
evidence.rdfs:label: Sarcomere Component

evidence.dc:description: Cardiomyocytes from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) patients showed higher Fpassive compared to control hearts and significantly lower Fpassive after PKD treatment. In addition, we found higher phosphorylation at CaMKII-dependent titin sites in HCM compared to control hearts. Expression and phosphorylation of HSP27, a substrate of PKD, were elevated in HCM hearts, which was associated with increased PKD expression and phosphorylation. The relocalization of HSP27 in HCM away from the sarcomeric Z-disk and I-band suggested that HSP27 failed to exert its protective action on titin extensibility. This protection could, however, be restored by administration of HSP27, which significantly reduced Fpassive in HCM cardiomyocytes.
evidence.rdfs:label: HCM Cell Expression

evidence.dc:description: TTN is highly expressed in heart muscle in GTex

evidence.dc:description: initial report
TTN missense (Arg740Leu) increased the binding affinity of titin to alpha-actitin in a yeast two-hybrid assay
evidence.rdfs:label: binding to alpha-actitin

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous change and a related phenotype that is not clearly recapitulating human HCM - 2 points reduced to 0.5

Reduced contractile response to beta-adrengergic agonists and extracellular calcium and reduced rate of calcium uptake in M-line deficient mice. Also reduced levels of calmodulin, phospholamban and SERCA1. Ca2+ sensitivity unchanged. Mice develop cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous change and a related phenotype that is not clearly recapitulating human HCM - 2 points reduced to 0.5
Adult mice missing exons 219-225 or N2B TTN develop diastolic dysfunction and hypertrophied hearts with upregulation of FHL proteins.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model

evidence.dc:description: left ventricular hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction are consistent with HCM.
evidence.rdfs:label: Medaka Fish
